title: Crossing epigenetic frontiers: the intersection of novel histone modifications and diseases

background: Histone post-translational modifications (HPTMs) are crucial for epigenetic regulation and are increasingly implicated in various diseases.
hypotheses: Novel HPTMs play crucial roles in the development and progression of various diseases.
Targeting novel HPTMs offers potential therapeutic strategies for multiple diseases.
Metabolic pathways are intricately linked to HPTMs and disease pathogenesis.
Advanced epigenetic research techniques are essential for understanding the complex interplay between HPTMs and disease.
major_findings: Nine novel HPTMs (lactylation, citrullination, crotonylation, succinylation, SUMOylation, propionylation, butyrylation, 2-hydroxyisobutyrylation, and 2-hydroxybutyrylation) were comprehensively reviewed.
These novel HPTMs are involved in various cellular processes, including transcription, replication, DNA repair, and metabolism.
Dysregulation of novel HPTMs is associated with the development and progression of various diseases, including cancers, cardiovascular diseases, infectious diseases, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
Novel HPTM inhibitors targeting various enzymes and pathways are emerging as potential therapeutic agents.
Advanced epigenetic research techniques, such as ChIP-seq, CUT&Tag, CUT&RUN, and mass spectrometry, are crucial for studying novel HPTMs.
